ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A good course if you are interested at relationships between Middle Eastern peoples and their environment, primarily through an anthropological lens.
Yes I would although I doubt the course will be offered again in the same form - since it was tied to this particular series of CMES talks.
One guest lecture and one hour of discussion a week. I would recommend the course if

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Generated more intellectual curiosity into how human beings interact with their environment, and specifically how this can be used as a different lens into understanding humans.

Not applicable since I'm not a graduate student (regarding the part about dissertation/research) - but in terms of learning more about MMES, definitely, since I had no knowledge of environmental issues in the region at all beforehand.

Hearing from a broad spectrum of people doing work in Middle East Studies now is of course tremendously useful to get a sense of where contemporary research is and is heading. The readings and some of the ideas in the discussions have been very helpful for thinking about my research going forward.
